docs.snippet: No Sour Grapes For Fox      The happiest people in town are at 20th Century Fox.    One year ago, executives at Fox and the other movie studios hung their collective heads. It was the year of the independent, when studios were virtually shut out o...
docs.lead_paragraph: No Sour Grapes For Fox The happiest people in town are at 20th Century Fox. One year ago, executives at Fox and the other movie studios hung their collective heads. It was the year of the independent, when studios were virtually shut out of the Academy Award race as Oscar nominations went to independent films like Miramax's ''English Patient,'' Fine Line's ''Shine'' and Gramercy's ''Fargo.''
docs.abstract: At the Movies column; this year's Academy Award nominations mark return of major studios; 20th Century Fox leads with 14 for Titanic and four for The Full Monty; Peter Chernin of News Corp, which controls Fox, comments; Gerald DiPego, 56-year-old onetime journalist who has worked for years as television and movie writer, hopes for success with film now being completed at Touchstone, tentatively titled Instinct; Anthony Hopkins and Cuba Gooding Jr star; Vanessa Redgrave comments on role in Mrs Dalloway, film adapted by Eileen Atkins from novel by Virginia Woolf; photos (S)

docs.snippet: Always charting its position in the home entertainment firmament, the video industry recently engaged Yankelovich Partners to determine why rentals of mainstream movies were down somewhat in 1997. After polling 1,807 people, Yankelovich concluded ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Always charting its position in the home entertainment firmament, the video industry recently engaged Yankelovich Partners to determine why rentals of mainstream movies were down somewhat in 1997. After polling 1,807 people, Yankelovich concluded that rentals were holding their own against all but one competitor. The exception was direct broadcast satellite, or DBS, which delivers as many as 55 channels of movies via an 18-inch dish. About 11 percent of those polled subscribed to a satellite service like DirecTV, and those who did said they had significantly cut down on trips to the video store.
docs.abstract: Home Video column; video industry recently engaged Yankelovich Partners to determine why rentals of mainstream movies were down in 1997; poll points to competition from satellite services; Paul Fishbein of Adult Video News comments on gains for 'adult' titles; four Paul Robeson films are released for Black History Month; photo (S)

docs.snippet: NEWS    For a Cause    With performers like Glenn Close, Whoopi Goldberg, Goldie Hawn, Kathy Najimy, Rosie Perez, Winona Ryder, Susan Sarandon and Maria Tomei delivering its soliloquies, Eve Ensler's Obie Award-winning play, ''The Vagina Monologue...
docs.lead_paragraph: NEWS For a Cause With performers like Glenn Close, Whoopi Goldberg, Goldie Hawn, Kathy Najimy, Rosie Perez, Winona Ryder, Susan Sarandon and Maria Tomei delivering its soliloquies, Eve Ensler's Obie Award-winning play, ''The Vagina Monologues,'' will return for one night, on Saturday. The Valentine's Day event, at 7 P.M. at the Hammerstein Ballroom Theater in midtown, is to benefit the V-Day fund to provide grants to groups that combat violence against women and girls. Curtain Call
docs.abstract: Eve Ensler's award-winning play, The Vagina Monologues, will return for one-night performance at Hammerstein Ballroom Theater in Manhattan; photo of Winona Ryder; Ingmar Bergman will direct Per Olov Enquist's The Picture Makers at Royal Dramatic Theater in Stockholm; Willie Nelson, singer and songwriter, joins Kickapoo Indian tribe of Kansas to start Outlaw Music Channel, satellite network dedicated to American Indian heritage and vintage country music; photo; Uffizi Gallery in Florence is reopening nine rooms damaged in Mafia bombing in 1993 that killed five people; fire causes minor damage to Historical Museum in Moscow during renovations (M)

docs.snippet: JACK MAGGS  By Peter Carey  Illustrated. 306 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $24.       At the opening of ''Jack Maggs,'' the sixth and latest novel by the Australian writer Peter Carey, the title character arrives by coach in London in mid-April 1837. ''...
docs.lead_paragraph: JACK MAGGS By Peter Carey Illustrated. 306 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $24. At the opening of ''Jack Maggs,'' the sixth and latest novel by the Australian writer Peter Carey, the title character arrives by coach in London in mid-April 1837. ''He was a tall man in his forties,'' the extravagant narrative informs us, ''so big in the chest and broad in the shoulder that his fellows on the bench seat had felt the strain of his presence, but what his occupation was, or what he planned to do in London, they had not the least idea.'' What Jack Maggs does in London is curious. He makes his way to Great Queen Street and knocks on the door of No. 27, ''rap-rap-rap,'' excited to behold this property at long last. When the maid from next door appears, tells him that the resident of 27 has gone away and asks him if by chance he's the new footman, Maggs announces that yes, he is a footman, and at once accepts a position as such in her household.
docs.abstract: Christopher Lehmann-Haupt reviews Peter Carey novel, Jack Maggs; photo (M)

docs.snippet: The great mystery of the winter movie season is what makes ''Titanic'' so popular. True, it was nominated for 14 Academy Awards yesterday, tied for the most ever. But the film is very long, the subject is literally a downer. Its best-known star, L...
docs.lead_paragraph: The great mystery of the winter movie season is what makes ''Titanic'' so popular. True, it was nominated for 14 Academy Awards yesterday, tied for the most ever. But the film is very long, the subject is literally a downer. Its best-known star, Leonardo DiCaprio, is a household name mainly in households that contain prepubescent girls. But ''Titanic'' could wind up becoming the biggest money-making movie in history. We have a suspicion about what makes this old story seem so fresh, but readers who have not yet seen the movie should be warned not to go farther. ''Titanic'' reintroduces an element long missing from Hollywood screenplays -- the dead hero. It is not very often you see a romantic lead killed off in a mainstream movie these days, a few war casualties notwithstanding. The triple-handkerchief conclusion of ''Titanic'' reminds us how attractive a deceased lover can be.
docs.abstract: Editorial on popularity of film Titanic cites appeal of dead hero (S)

docs.snippet: Gloria Stuart was asleep at her home in West Los Angeles when her visiting daughter and son-in-law woke her up and began jumping up and down to tell her she had just been nominated for an Academy Award for her supporting role in ''Titanic.'' Ms. S...
docs.lead_paragraph: Gloria Stuart was asleep at her home in West Los Angeles when her visiting daughter and son-in-law woke her up and began jumping up and down to tell her she had just been nominated for an Academy Award for her supporting role in ''Titanic.'' Ms. Stuart, 87, said later, ''All these years -- I've been waiting for this a long, long time.'' Gus Van Sant, who was nominated as best director for ''Good Will Hunting,'' said his parents cried when he called them with the news. And Robert Forster, who has struggled for years as an actor, heard from some unlikely callers that he had been nominated for an Oscar for Quentin Tarantino's ''Jackie Brown.''
docs.abstract: Academy Award nominations are announced; Titanic, James Cameron epic, is nominated for 14 Academy Awards, including best picture, actress and direction; LA Confidential and Good Will Hunting receive nine nominations each, including best picture; other films nominated for best picture are As Good As It Gets and The Full Monty; Uberto Pasolini, producer of The Full Monty, says he is 'flabbergasted' at best-film nomination, which was relative surprise in film industry; list of nominations (L)

headline.main: 'Titanic' Leads the Oscar List With 'L.A.' and 'Good Will'

docs.snippet: Oscar De La Hoya's mandatory defense of his World Boxing Council welterweight title against the No. 1 contender, Patrick Charpentier, has been postponed two weeks after De La Hoya sprained his left wrist sparring last weekend at his training camp ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Oscar De La Hoya's mandatory defense of his World Boxing Council welterweight title against the No. 1 contender, Patrick Charpentier, has been postponed two weeks after De La Hoya sprained his left wrist sparring last weekend at his training camp at Coachella, Calif. De La Hoya was examined yesterday in Palm Springs, and the doctor determined that the wrist was sprained. De La Hoya will have to stay away from sparring for a week, but he should be able to continue his road work. The wrist is expected to heal in two weeks, but the injury means the entire card -- which includes Keith Mullings of Brooklyn defending his W.B.C. junior-middleweight title against David Ciarlante -- will be moved to March 14 at Trump's Taj Mahal in Atlantic City.
docs.abstract: Oscar De La Hoya's defense of his World Boxing Council welterweight title against Patrick Charpentier is postponed two weeks after De La Hoya sprains his left wrist while sparring (S)

docs.snippet: As expected, Helen Hunt secured a nomination for the Academy Award for best actress yesterday, leaving NBC to continue to worry if she will lean toward establishing a full-time film career, abandoning her role on ''Mad About You.''    It was the f...
docs.lead_paragraph: As expected, Helen Hunt secured a nomination for the Academy Award for best actress yesterday, leaving NBC to continue to worry if she will lean toward establishing a full-time film career, abandoning her role on ''Mad About You.'' It was the first time that an actor or actress still starring in a television series was nominated for an Oscar for best actor or actress.
docs.abstract: Helen Hunt's nomination for Academy Award for best actress causes NBC to worry if she will abandon her television show, Mad About You, for full-time career in films (S)

headline.main: TV Notes; Defecting to the Movies?

docs.snippet: Brilliant blue skies gave Californians a chance to dry out today, offering a respite from Pacific storms that have battered the coast like artillery barrages.    So far, the toll from a week of storms stands at 7 dead in California and 13 dead in ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Brilliant blue skies gave Californians a chance to dry out today, offering a respite from Pacific storms that have battered the coast like artillery barrages. So far, the toll from a week of storms stands at 7 dead in California and 13 dead in and around Tijuana, Mexico. From Northern California to Baja California, Mexico, about 2,000 buildings have been damaged or destroyed, and thousands of families have been evacuated to shelters.
docs.abstract: California enjoys respite from Pacific storms that have battered coast for days, leaving seven dead and about 2,000 buildings damaged or destroyed; forecasters expect new storm to hit coast on February 10; photo; map (M)

headline.main: California Recovers in Lull Between Storms
